messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: A few years agoI was looking at a suit of armor with the hinged cutout on the chest piece. It was made to open to the right instead of left. The owner said it
messages.messageBody:
A few years agoI was looking at a suit of armor with
the hinged cutout on the chest piece. It was made to
open to the right instead of left. The owner said it
was made for a left handed samurai. He said before
Tokugawa era there were the standard amount of left
handed samurai as any population but that after Edo
started they were forced to change. FWIW BOb Elder

> wear with the cutting edge down. I don't know of any

> right handed wear. I might add that to the best of

> such thing as an entirely left-handed person.
> Left-handed individuals either

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: Hi John, If you refer to the Tokyo National Museum s publication on Uchigatana Koshirae, you will note several Tensho period mounts arranged for wear on the
messages.messageBody:
Hi John,



If you refer to the Tokyo National Museum's publication on Uchigatana
Koshirae, you will note several Tensho period mounts arranged for wear on
the right side. There is some question as to whether or not they were for
wear with the cutting edge down. I don't know of any illustrations showing
right handed wear. I might add that to the best of my knowledge there is no
such thing as an entirely left-handed person. Left-handed individuals either
due to nurture or nature seem to do some things with the right-hand and
others with the left and sometimes able to use both for the same thing.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: John Lissenden [mailto:docliss@...]
Sent: Tuesday, December 21, 2004 12:10 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword



To inject a slightly more serious note into the smugness of your 'leftie'
members ...

Do any members KNOW if left-handedness was extant among early Japanese
swordsmen. I have never, personally, seen illustrations of samurai wearing
their swords on the right side, and it is not inconceivable that they were
trained at an early age to use their swords in the conventional manner. The
only advantage in being left handed is, surely, its comparative rarity and
strangeness to a right-handed opponent.

Interestingly, I have in my collection (WAY 386.27.ex Gardiner collection)
an unsigned, shakudo fuchi-gashira, attributed to Hirata Harunari This has
an ishime surface, with takaramono in a shippo of coloured enamels within
gold cloissons. The ura surface of the fuchi has had an additional
takaramono added in gold lacquer, and this may possibly be to facilitate its
wearing on the right side by presenting a more decorative surface. I can
think of no other possible explanation for this modification.

John L.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: To inject a slightly more serious note into the smugness of your leftie members ... Do any members KNOW if left-handedness was extant among early Japanese
messages.messageBody:
To inject a slightly more serious note into the smugness of your 'leftie' members ...

Do any members KNOW if left-handedness was extant among early Japanese swordsmen. I have never, personally, seen illustrations of samurai wearing their swords on the right side, and it is not inconceivable that they were trained at an early age to use their swords in the conventional manner. The only advantage in being left handed is, surely, its comparative rarity and strangeness to a right-handed opponent.

Interestingly, I have in my collection (WAY 386.27.ex Gardiner collection) an unsigned, shakudo fuchi-gashira, attributed to Hirata Harunari This has an ishime surface, with takaramono in a shippo of coloured enamels within gold cloissons. The ura surface of the fuchi has had an additional takaramono added in gold lacquer, and this may possibly be to facilitate its wearing on the right side by presenting a more decorative surface. I can think of no other possible explanation for this modification.

John L.

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Musashi's sword
messages.msgSnippet: Of course, most of the best ones were/are. Not that I am in anyway bias you understand. Richard Turner  wrote:and the only thing
messages.messageBody:
Of course, most of the best ones were/are. Not that I am in anyway bias you understand.

Richard Turner <ikkanshi@...> wrote:and the only thing better than a lefty is a left handed artist :-)

Rich


paul bowman wrote:

> Us left handers have long understood the uniqueness and superiority of
> being a lefty:-) Its just taken the rest of the world a while to
> cotton-on.
> yours in true leftist smugness
> paul
